title: 103_hr2892
content: The Act is titled the "Violent Crime Control and Regional Prison Partnership Act of 1993". It establishes federal-state partnerships for regional prisons. The Attorney General is required to establish a Regional Prison Task Force and create a plan for a nationwide regional prison system within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The plan will define the boundaries and number of regions for regional prisons. The Attorney General will establish regional prisons and partnership agreements with States for participation. The Federal Bureau of Prisons will administer the prisons, and States will share responsibilities. States must cover at least 50% of construction and operating costs. States must enter into a partnership agreement to send prisoners to regional prisons. The partnership agreement requires states to establish minimum mandatory sentences for serious felonies involving violence with a firearm or sexual assault. A truth in sentencing policy mandates offenders to serve at least 85% of their sentence for these crimes. The partnership agreement mandates states to establish minimum mandatory sentences for violent felonies involving firearms or sexual assault. States must also provide pretrial detention similar to the Federal system and eliminate court-imposed limitations on prison capacity. Additionally, states must assure that regional prison systems will not replace their own and provide additional funds for construction and operation of regional prisons. Prisoners convicted of specific violent crimes or serious drug offenses may be sent to regional prisons established by eligible states. The term "crime of violence" refers to a felony punishable by more than one year of imprisonment. The term "serious felony" refers to a felony punishable by more than one year of imprisonment, involving the use of physical force against another person. The term "crime of violence involving a sexual assault" is defined as a violent offense under chapter 109A of title 18, US Code. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other US territories. The United States establishes the Regional Prison Fund in the Treasury, consisting of appropriated sums, criminal fines exceeding $150,000,000, and remaining assets from the Department of Justice Asset Forfeiture Fund as determined by the Attorney General. The Regional Prison Fund in the Treasury holds appropriated sums, criminal fines over $150,000,000, and assets from the Department of Justice Asset Forfeiture Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury can transfer funds as needed, and the Attorney General can use the fund for law enforcement purposes. Authorization of appropriations includes $1 billion for each fiscal year from 1994 to 1996, and additional funds through 2004.
